pros:
I have done psychological and parenting evaluations at BNC for 30 years, usually when clients are involved with Court.  I  like coming up with ideas on how clients can improve their parenting skills, learning problems, mood or substance situation. l am grateful to BNC's fine support staff, who schedule clients, fix my computer problems, do accurate billing, and maintain really  excellent and detailed medical records. I am impressed by the quality of BNC's therapists and medical staff.  I value BNC's flexibility, since if I go to Court on one day or if I hate mornings (so true!) then I can adjust my schedule from week to week since I work part-time. I am pleased that the Douglas County District Court judges support recommendations for mental health services.  
       The last 30 years were not always easy, but they are absolutely worth it.
cons: It can be hard to put in the required number of billable hours that staff are supposed to achieve, because client no-shows and required paperwork and transportation to clients/Court reduce the time that a staff person can bill for.

pros: I feel supported in my work as a crisis therapist because my supervisor, team members, and director promote a culture of mutual-aid, team work, and innovation. We have incredibly challenging jobs that require flexibility and innovative problem solving. I appreciate opportunities to be involved in systems level change and conversations that impact our clients' care and agency culture. I feel there are avenues to create change and be heard within the organization. I'm able to sustain my work because I have fun with my colleagues, and I feel like I serve my community in a meaningful way.
cons: I feel more progressive leave and paid time off polices would be inline with the mission and vision of Bert Nash, as well as attractive to job seekers. To be sustainable in the field of mental health, the people doing the work need to be able to create and model balanced living. I believe there is work to be done to increase paid time off to prioritize work, family, and leisure in a more equal measures.
